item.title: China bans hidden car door handles, which can trap people after crashes
item.description: China has introduced new regulations, starting in 2027, requiring all car doors to open manually from both sides. Electric door handles can malfunction in a crash or battery failure.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Here's why people say they're using 'Are You Dead?' and apps like it
item.description: Safety check-in apps — a way for loved ones to know that you're alive — have become more popular among adults who feel that modern life has made connection and community more difficult to maintain.

item.title: Schools in China are making AI part of the curriculum
item.description: While debate rages in the U.S. about the merits and risks of AI in schools, it a state-mandated part of the curriculum in China, as the authorities try to create a pool of AI-savvy professionals.

item.description: The company announced it was ending production of its higher-end Model S and Model Y, and turning that production space over to making humanoid robots.

item.description: The rewrite was done to speed up the construction of a new generation of nuclear reactors. Critics warn it could compromise safety and public trust.

item.title: Bystander videos have long shaped public opinion of police violence
item.description: Bystander videos have shaped public perception for decades. The ability to now spread video widely can lead to real-time access and transparency, but experts say videos can't tell the full story.
